title: Crunchy Asian Ramen Noodle Salad (a.k.a. Basically the Best Potluck Salad EVER)
summary: Crunchy Asian Ramen Noodle Salad (a.k.a. Basically the Best Potluck Salad EVER) might be just the side dish you are searching for. One serving contains 393 calories, 8g of protein, and 26g of fat. For $1.52 per serving, this recipe covers 16% of your daily requirements of vitamins and minerals. This recipe serves 8. 1694 people were impressed by this recipe. This recipe is typical of Japanese cuisine. Head to the store and pick up thinly- almonds, thinly- green onions, avocado oil, and a few other things to make it today. From preparation to the plate, this recipe takes about 10 minutes. It is a good option if you're following a dairy free diet. All things considered, we decided this recipe deserves a spoonacular score of 88%. This score is tremendous. Try Crunchy Asian Ramen Noodle Salad (Pretty Much The Best Potluck Salad EVER), Broccoli Ramen Noodle Salad | Perfect Party or Potluck Side, and Crisp and Crunchy Asian Ramen Salad for similar recipes.

winePairing.pairingText: Riesling, Sake, and Sauvignon Blanc are my top picks for Ramen Noodles. Saké is an obvious choice when it comes to Japanese food. If you want to stick to grape wine, though, you might opt for sauvignon blanc or riesling. One wine you could try is Dr. Thanisch Graacher Himmelreich Spatlese Riesling. It has 4.5 out of 5 stars and a bottle costs about 19 dollars.

productMatches.title: Dr. Thanisch Graacher Himmelreich Spatlese Riesling
productMatches.description: Graach is an excellent wine growing village in the heart of the Middle Mosel. The steep slopes of the Graacher Himmelreich vineyard are facing South-West. They are exclusively planted with Riesling.The nose displays a sweet floral quality of plummeria, fresh peach with a touch of petrol character which is common in German wines. Often the more age a German wine has, the stronger the petrol character. There is nothing wrong with wines with this aroma. This 2003 vintage, only shows a slight – medium petrol aroma. Brimful with character, the Himmelreich Spätlese palate is a wonderful mix of peach, honey and mango. The medium weight interplays enticingly with the finely bound acidity.

instructions: To Make The Salad:(Optional first step: Heat oven to 425 degrees. Spread the crumbled ramen noodles and sliced almonds out on a baking sheet, and stir a bit to combine. Bake for about 5 minutes, or until the almonds and noodles are slightly toasted and golden. Remove baking sheet, and give the mixture a good stir to toss. Then return it to the oven and toast for an additional 3 minutes. Keep a very close eye on the mixture so that it does not burn. Remove and set aside.)Add ingredients (including the vinaigrette) together in a large bowl, and toss until combined.Serve immediately, or cover and refrigerate for up to 3 days. (This salad is much better eaten the first day, as the noodles lose their "crunch" the longer it sits, and the avocado may brown a bit. Still, it's perfectly edible and enjoyable even after a few days!)To Make The Vinaigrette:Whisk all ingredients together until combined.

analyzedInstructions.name: To Make The Salad(Optional first step

steps.step: Spread the crumbled ramen noodles and sliced almonds out on a baking sheet, and stir a bit to combine.
Bake for about 5 minutes, or until the almonds and noodles are slightly toasted and golden.
Remove baking sheet, and give the mixture a good stir to toss. Then return it to the oven and toast for an additional 3 minutes. Keep a very close eye on the mixture so that it does not burn.
Add ingredients (including the vinaigrette) together in a large bowl, and toss until combined.

analyzedInstructions.name: Serve immediately, or cover and refrigerate for up to 3 days. (This salad is much better eaten the first day, as the noodles lose their "crunch" the longer it sits, and the avocado may brown a bit. Still, it's perfectly edible and enjoyable even after a few days!)To Make The Vinaigrette

steps.step: Whisk all ingredients together until combined.
